name: Xochiquetzal
subtitle: Aztec goddess of fertility
blurb: In the pantheon of supervocalic discoveries,Xochiquetzal reigns supereme. She is the embodiment of the Divine Feminine and all it represents. Like a true goddess, she nurtures—welcoming not only all vowels, but high-scoring Scrabble tiles J,Q, and X which others find "difficult". And she does this in one solid word, without repeating a letter, leading with the rare and sultry "X"—all as if to say "I got this". The supervocalic Mother Goddess, watches over the mortal Montezuma I.
AskDmitri: OIUEA Rossif Sutherland 80 Shoji Ueda 75 Corin Curschellas 73 Moritz Gudemann 68 Florin Prunea 62 Xochiquetzal - Aztec goddess of fertility

name: Douglas Leigh
subtitle: Urban installation visionary
blurb: Douglas Leigh's "urban installations", are some of the most enduring concepts of the 20th century. He personally oversaw the transformation of Times Square into a nocturnal neon extravangza (once owning One Times Square, where the ball drops on New Year's Eve), and came up with the idea to light the Empire State Building red, white, and blue during the bicentennial, starting a grand tradition. Now, that's a light bulb of an idea.
AskDmitri: OUAEI Douglas Feith 80 Jourdan Lewis 80 Joshua Ferris 75 Mourad Meghni 72 Douglas Evill 70

name: Count Basie

His official bio was actually called The Deeds of Louis the Fat, and that was written by a close friend. But he was strong leader, and strong entry for the OUEIA slot. Among other French contributions, let us not forget designer Louis Réard, inventor of the bikini.

name: Gustav Weisskopf
subtitle: German-American aviation pioneer
blurb: Gustav Weisskopf (later, Gustave Whitehead) needed either a better publicist, or a scolding for telling tales. He either conquered powered manned flight numerous times years before the Wright Brothers—leaving eyewitness but no photographic evidence—or repeatedly lied about the same along with supposed onlookers. His bio is a good read either way.

name: Juan Diego
subtitle: Canonized Mexican native - "San Diego"
blurb: The first indigenous Mexican saint, Juan Diego—born Cuauhtlatoatzin—is our 3rd Nahuatl entry. His visions of the Virgin of Guadeloupe became celebrated worldwide. The name "Diego" evolved from a family of names related to "Jacob" (San Diego < Santiago < Sancto Iacobo < Iacobo < Iakobos < Jacob > Iacobus > Iacomus > James).
